abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Second Highway Project in Zimbabwe. The
            primary objective of the project was to reduce the backlog
            of periodic maintenance of primary, secondary, and feeder
            roads. Bank's performance was highly satisfactory.
            Borrower's performance was highly satisfactory. The key
            lessons learned were as follows: (i) government's
            commitment alone does not guarantee the allocation of
            adequate funds for a project; (ii) the decision to address
            maintenance requirements at a time when most projects
            focused on new construction and rehabilitation yielded high
            returns; (iii) parallel reforms, such as to develop and
            maintain the capacity of the construction industry, must
            move in consort with changes in how roads are maintained;
            and (iv) the usual time frames provided for are too
            optimistic and that more effective change could ensue from
            more realistic programming.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Highway Project's
            objective is to strengthen the state road network in
            commercial farming areas as well as in communal lands by
            reducing the backlog of the periodic maintenance of primary,
            secondary and feeder roads. The project comprises : (1)
            strengthening and rehabilitation of nine sections of paved
            roads totalling 175 km; (2) resealing of about 1500 km of
            paved roads; (3) regravelling of about 1500 km of secondary
            and feeder roads; (4) low-cost improvement of about 1400 km
            of secondary and feeder roads; and (5) consultants to
            prepare detailed engineering studies and to supervise
            strengthening and rehabilitation of paved roads.
